channel.title: Making a Scripting Langague
channel.description: I was just wondering if it were possible to do this, reason I ask is because I have the idea of writing a scripting language for the Robot class, just something I think would be cool. Anything?

item.title: Making a Scripting Langague
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“s1gma, post:15, topic:468168”][quote author=The Web Guy link=topic=585129.msg4160645#msg4160645 date=1353071130]
Yes it’s possible, if it wasn’t, we wouldn’t have the current scripting languages available. You can create it by using resources from the basic Windows files. DLL files act as resource libraries for several functions in a program, if you know how to use them correctly, it’s completely possible.
[/quote]stick with the web bro[/quote]

Maybe I should :L

Read full topic

@The_Web_Guy wrote:

Yes it’s possible, if it wasn’t, we wouldn’t have the current scripting languages available. You can create it by using resources from the basic Windows files. DLL files act as resource libraries for several functions in a program, if you know how to use them correctly, it’s completely possible.

item.title: Making a Scripting Langague
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Tree, post:8, topic:468168”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=585129.msg4159125#msg4159125 date=1352908877]

Yes it’s possible. You write the syntax, you control the flow. The only thing you’d really need to know how to do is use reflection to access fields and methods from various classes.
You might use regex too, to make sure the syntax is correct.

Or you could use an existing scripting language that has Java support. I like Clojure. It’s a lisp dialect. It uses prefix operators though, so it might take some getting used to.

Oh nonono not regex. You would want to use a grammar and either implement it by hand or use a combination of a lexical generator (such as jflex or jlex) and a parser generator (javacc or yacc with a java target).

@OP: long story short, this is way more work than you envision and isn’t going to be worth it. Just use javascript, jruby, jython, groovy, or some other targetable scripting language and link to the Robot class.
[/quote]

I disagree. Give it a shot and learn from it.
Even if it does take a lot more effort, you will gain so much more.[/quote]

I’m not disagreeing with the idea of learning from experience. My point was his goal is far overscope. He’ll end up spending more time learning how languages work than actually accomplishing his goal. In almost all cases, that leads to the original problem never being solved. If he really wants to do both, he can use a practical solution to his current problem and later go and learn how languages work. Why encourage someone to go five hundred miles out of the way for a cup of coffee when they can just go down the street for one? Sure, the adventure is great, but let them get their coffee first!

Read full topic

item.title: Making a Scripting Langague
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:10, topic:468168”][quote author=Whackatre link=topic=585129.msg4159021#msg4159021 date=1352894205]

@All the scripting languages posted above: How would I set it up though to interpret? Like, certain functions = methods and such.

GitHub

jruby/jruby

jruby - JRuby, an implementation of Ruby on the JVM


github.com

jtzeng/stratoflyer/blob/master/src/net/skyrealm/flyer/util/ScriptManager.java

/*
 * StratoFlyer is a simple 2D space shooter built for educational purposes.
 * Copyright (C) 2012	Justin Zeng (Whackatre)
 *
 * This program is free software: you can redistribute it and/or modify
 * it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
 * the Free Software Foundation, either version 3 of the License, or
 * (at your option) any later version.
 *
 * This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
 * but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
 * MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
 * GNU General Public License for more details.
 *
 * You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
 * along with this program.  If not, see <http://www.gnu.org/licenses/>.
 */

package net.skyrealm.flyer.util;
This file has been truncated. show original

[/quote]
Hmm, I like it. I use codeacademy for learning JS and Python right now, can you give a grade on the accuracy of their ruby courses?

@sinisoul: Then what would be the best way of approaching this? I personally would prefer to make one over using an existing one, since that would actually give me more of a sense of accomplishment.[/quote]

i have no idea; i’ve never used those before. i would suggest http://rubymonk.com as i find it quite nice.

Read full topic

item.title: Making a Scripting Langague
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Tree, post:8, topic:468168”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=585129.msg4159125#msg4159125 date=1352908877]

Yes it’s possible. You write the syntax, you control the flow. The only thing you’d really need to know how to do is use reflection to access fields and methods from various classes.
You might use regex too, to make sure the syntax is correct.

Or you could use an existing scripting language that has Java support. I like Clojure. It’s a lisp dialect. It uses prefix operators though, so it might take some getting used to.

Oh nonono not regex. You would want to use a grammar and either implement it by hand or use a combination of a lexical generator (such as jflex or jlex) and a parser generator (javacc or yacc with a java target).

@OP: long story short, this is way more work than you envision and isn’t going to be worth it. Just use javascript, jruby, jython, groovy, or some other targetable scripting language and link to the Robot class.
[/quote]

I disagree. Give it a shot and learn from it.
Even if it does take a lot more effort, you will gain so much more.[/quote]

This. There’s a great deal you will learn even by putting forth the effort.

Read full topic

Yes it’s possible. You write the syntax, you control the flow. The only thing you’d really need to know how to do is use reflection to access fields and methods from various classes.
You might use regex too, to make sure the syntax is correct.

Or you could use an existing scripting language that has Java support. I like Clojure. It’s a lisp dialect. It uses prefix operators though, so it might take some getting used to.
[/quote]

Oh nonono not regex. You would want to use a grammar and either implement it by hand or use a combination of a lexical generator (such as jflex or jlex) and a parser generator (javacc or yacc with a java target).

@OP: long story short, this is way more work than you envision and isn’t going to be worth it. Just use javascript, jruby, jython, groovy, or some other targetable scripting language and link to the Robot class.[/quote]

Even if it does take a lot more effort, you will gain so much more.
